title: 500,000 Lives Lost
content:
500,000
lives lost

The scale of the COVID-19 death toll in the United States

As the trickle of fatalities increased, state agencies scrambled to track deaths with varying degrees of delay. The data below reflects deaths on the date reported, and not necessarily the day someone died.

Frank Gabrin, 60
Harlem, N.Y.

An E.R. doctor and one of the first U.S. physicians known to have died from COVID-19, Gabrin was someone who leapt into the fray without hesitation and was eager to help his patients at the onset of the pandemic.

Died March 31, 2020

Saul Sanchez, 78
Greeley, Colo.

The grandfather of 13 earned his GED at age 60 and had just recently celebrated working 30 years at JBS Beef Company.

Died April 17, 2020

George Trefren, 90
Denver, Colo.

Returned from the Korean War in 1953, got married and had four children and operated a small construction business.

Died April 23, 2020

Jose Holguin, 50
New York, N.Y.

Came to the U.S. as a teenager from the Dominican Republic. Worked at a grocery store, at a barber shop, and as a handyman. He used the money he earned to rebuild his mother’s home, and his children went to visit her nearly every summer.

Died April 28, 2020

Madhvi Aya, 61
Floral Park, N.Y.

Physician assistant at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn. An immigrant from India, she was described by her family as a hard-worker and an optimist. She would wake up at 4am for her 12-hour shifts at the hospital and kiss her sleeping daughter on the forehead before leaving.

Died March 29, 2020

Cheryl Burch, 61
Davison, Michigan

An avid motorcyclist, she was passionate about her work as a fraud examiner, an enthusiastic clarinet player, and avid concert-goer.

Died June 4, 2020

Nur Omar Mohamed, 67
Minneapolis, Minn.

Came to the United States as a refugee from Somalia in 1995 during the country’s civil war and eventually settled in Minneapolis. His daughter, Ilhan Omar, was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2018.

Died June 15, 2020

David Gutierrez, 53
Houston, Texas

A software engineer who raised 5 children with his wife, Michelle. They would have celebrated their ten-year wedding anniversary in September.

Died Aug. 14, 2020

Judy Mason, 83
Hutchinson, Kan.

Opened Judy's School of Dance in 1964 and taught thousands of students until the time of her death. Loved family reunions, trips and board games. She was a devoted Catholic and member of the prison ministry to comfort the incarcerated.

Died Nov. 11, 2020

Florence Bolton, 86
Chicago, Ill.

Taught Special Education for over 35 years despite being diagnosed as legally blind. She loved aerobics, line dancing, the farmers’ market and large family gatherings.

Died Dec. 2, 2020

Charlie Pride, 86
Dallas, Texas

A Mississippi native who picked cotton, served in the U.S. Army and played baseball in the Negro league before moving to Nashville, becoming the first Black country star. He joined the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2000.

Died Dec. 12, 2020

Jose Garcia, 68
La Mesa, N.M.

A farmworker who raised 9 children after immigrating from Mexico as a teenager.

Died Dec. 15, 2020

Dawn Wells, 82
Los Angeles, Calif.

An actress best known for her role as Mary Ann Summers, one of seven castaways stranded after their boat, the S.S. Minnow, became battered in a storm during what was supposed to be a three-hour tour from Hawaii.

Died Dec. 30, 2020

Gregory Blanks, 50
Bellville, Texas

Ran a heating and air conditioning business in the Houston area and was a huge fan of the Dallas Cowboys football team.

Died Jan. 17, 2021

Bill Mason, 81
Hutchinson, Kan.

A well-respected businessman who mentored many. Had 27 grandchildren, and 37 great grandchildren.

Died Oct. 21, 2020

February 6, 2020

A 57-year-old Santa Clara County, California, woman became the country's first known COVID-19 casualty.

February 17, 2020

The second U.S. COVID-19 death occurred 11 days later. Both were initially misclassified, but later identified as COVID-19-related by Santa Clara County from tissue samples.

February 29, 2020

A man died at a Seattle-area nursing home that became the setting of the country’s first COVID-19 cluster.

March 13, 2020

The fast-spreading coronavirus prompted President Donald Trump to declare a national emergency to free up $50 billion in federal aid.

March 30, 2020

3,377 dead: more than the September 11, 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center.

April 17, 2020

37,321 dead: more than the total U.S. military casualties in the Korean War.

April 28, 2020

58,713 dead: more than the total U.S. military casualties in the Vietnam War.

May 8, 2020

The Labor Department said more than 20 million jobs vanished in April, the most since the Great Depression, as the unemployment rate soared to a post-World War Two record.

The unemployment rate gradually improved in the months ahead as many local economies reopened. But chronic joblessness remained endemic in the coronavirus era.

May 27, 2020

The U.S. coronavirus death toll hit its first morbid milestone of 100,000 deaths, even as a slowdown in the pace of new casualties encouraged states to allow businesses to reopen and Americans to emerge from more than two months of lockdowns.

June 16, 2020

117,080 dead: more than the total U.S. military deaths in World War One.

December 9, 2020

3,384 died on this day alone, exceeding the September 11, 2001 attacks death toll.

January 20, 2021

405,830 dead: more than the total U.S. military deaths in World War Two.

September 22, 2020

200,000 dead: The country's second 100,000-death milestone took a little longer to reach than the first one as daily COVID-19 fatalities slowed to 800 from more than 2,800 on April 15. More than 70% of the 200,000 victims were over 65 years old.

October 2, 2020

Trump broke the news to his Twitter followers in the early morning hours that he and first lady Melania tested positive for the coronavirus. Several other White House aides, supporters and governors would also test positive in the days following. After treatment, Trump returned to the White House three days later.

About the data

Reuters collates and checks this data by hand, and the figures largely come from state, county and territory government/public health department websites. Deaths include both confirmed and probable cases.

Some sudden spikes in recorded deaths are due to reporting backlogs. For example, a spike in late June 2020 is due to New Jersey including over 1,800 probable deaths from earlier in the pandemic. Similar spikes occurred in February 2021 as Indiana and Ohio reported deaths that had occurred earlier in the pandemic.

Reporting by Emily Isaacman, Arundhati Sarkar, Yajush Gupta, Sabahatjahan Contractor, Chinmay Rautmare, Roshan Abraham, Lisa Shumaker, Christine Chan, Wen Foo, Aditya Munjuluru, Anurag Maan, Nikhil Subba, K. Sathya Narayanan, Ahmed Farhatha, Aniruddha Chakrabarty, Mrinalika Roy, Abhishek Manikandan, Arpit Nayak, Chaithra J, Shaina Ahluwalia, Shreyasee Raj, Shashank Nayar, Nallur Sethuraman, Harshith Aranya and Gautami Khandke. Additional reporting by David Gregorio and Aurora Ellis.

Sources

Deaths data from state and local governments and health authorities; Reuters reporting; U.S. Navy

Edited by

Jon McClure, Lisa Shumaker
author: John Gruber
